awd_titl_txt: Coarse-Graining of Molecular Liquids in Time and Space
awd_abstract_narration:
Marina Guenza of the University of Oregon is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry.  Dr. Guenza develops computational and theoretical methods to study complex molecular liquid. Such computer simulations are useful because they can explain experimental findings based on the molecular nature of the liquid. However, they have severe limitations in the size of the system that they can study.   To allow simulation of larger systems, Guenza and coworkers employ a kind of coarse graining, the Integral Equation theory of Coarse-Graining (IECG).   This approach uses only essential details   in the description of the molecules thereby reducing computational time.  This allows for the study of large and more complex systems. The method has been shown to be very accurate in its predictions of structural, thermodynamic, and dynamical properties. Further optimization of the method, its extension to many systems, and making the method accessible to the scientists that want to use it, are the main goals of this project. A second aspect of the project focuses on the further development of an approach to study proteins, nuclear acids and their complexes. Guenza and her research group engage in outreach activities to high school students from rural Oregon school districts. 

The focus of this research is to extend the range of length scales and time scales where complex molecular liquids can be simulated.  In the first project, Guenza and coworkers are extending the capabilities of the Integral Equation theory of Coarse-Graining (IECG) approach to treat non-uniform molecular liquids, for example, at solid interfaces. In the second project, they are working to extend the Langevin Equation for Protein Dynamics (LE4PD) to treat proteins, nucleic acids, and their complexes. The approach is based on a Langevin equation for the dynamics of macromolecules in solution, which also accounts for the presence of local conformational barriers and the internal hydrophobic region in the macromolecule. Developing the theory to describe the long-time barrier-crossing dynamics by integration with Markov State Models is a key component of this work.

por.por_cntn:
With the support of the NSF grant, the Guenza group developed original coarse-grained theories for the structure, thermodynamics, and dynamics of complex macromolecular systems, both synthetic and biological. Coarse-grained models, when combined through a multiscale modeling procedure, extend the capabilities of traditional atomistic computer simulations.

Atomistic computer simulations are an essential support in scientific research as they enable one to link the molecular structure of a system to its overall properties, as measured though various experimental methods. Nonetheless, such simulations have limitations, including the size of the systems that can be simulated and the longest timescale that can be measured, making it challenging to directly compare simulation results to experimental outcomes. To overcome these limitations, coarse-grained methods simplify the structure of the system simulated, allowing for the simulation of larger systems and longer timescales.

The Guenza group has created a set of coarse-grained models that offer a significant boost in the speed of simulations for polymer liquids, all while maintaining a high level of accuracy in predicting their structural, thermodynamic, and dynamic properties. These models can be an essential asset for researchers who study polymer liquids, providing them with a highly precise tool for their investigations.

The Integral Equation Coarse-Grained (IECG) model represents polymer melts as liquids of coarse-grained chains. What makes this model unique is that its equation of state remains consistent at different coarse-grained resolution, allowing for optimal computational efficiency and accuracy. When using multiple coarse-grained models in one multiscale simulations, the resulting polymer liquid is a blend of polymers represented at different resolutions that do not phase separate. This thermodynamic stability is crucial when combining coarse-grained models that have different resolution into one multiscale computational scheme. Furthermore, compared to atomistic simulations, the IECG simulations result in significant computational gains, providing highly accurate predictions of the equation of state (pressure) and structure (pair distribution functions) with several orders of magnitude computational gain.

The Langevin Equation for Protein Dynamics (LE4PD) models the dynamics of biopolymers in a coarse-grained representation. LE4PD accurately identifies and measures the pathways of slow dynamics in proteins and nucleic acids. These slow modes play a crucial role in many biological processes, such as protein binding to DNA through the conformational selection mechanism. LE4PD has been integrated with a Markov State Model analysis of the mode trajectories to identify slow dynamics and rare events in the simulation. This method is more precise in identifying slow dynamics than traditional methods such as Principal Component Analysis (PCA) or the time-lagged Independent Component Analysis (tICA) methods because it includes hydrodynamics. In addition, the slowest LE4PD mode has been found to guide the unfolding process in the protein ubiquitin.

A significant portion of the professional efforts in the Guenza group goes into training undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral associates to become active researchers in the field of theoretical physical chemistry. All the computational codes related to the coarse-grained models developed with NSF support are available to the scientific community in the GuenzaLab GitHub repository.
